text:
I’m writing a super-detailed post about the first 18-ish months of the content team at <http://crossbeam.com/|Crossbeam>, a B2B SaaS company that makes tools for partnerships. What would you like to know about the early days of a content org? Will answer here before putting in post. AMA.

Three stats:
• 14% avg month-over-month traffic growth
• Built email list of 20,000+ with open rate of 40%
• 125+ keywords in top 10 of Google
Our traffic since our first content hire:

text:
<@U01T8TVMUSD> Hires went like this:
1 - Content Marketing Manager <@U01B4AN2WMC> (sept 2020)
2 - Staff Writer Olivia Ramirez (sept 2020)
3 - Brand Designer Nick Beaulieu (was at company, joined content team in Jan 2021)

We hired as soon as we confirmed we had audience/publication/product alignment. I.e. the people we were writing for were the ones that got the most use out of using the product.

elements.text:
Hires went like this:
1 - Content Marketing Manager

(sept 2020)
2 - Staff Writer Olivia Ramirez (sept 2020)
3 - Brand Designer Nick Beaulieu

(was at company, joined content team in Jan 2021)

We hired as soon as we confirmed we had audience/publication/product alignment. I.e. the people we were writing for were the ones that got the most use out of using the product.

text: Thanks <@UJE5LQ2JC>! what kind of work/tasks composed the majority of your brand designers time?

elements.text: Thanks
! what kind of work/tasks composed the majority of your brand designers time?

text: <@UJ7RT1J1X> we had a hunch it was partner managers but we werent sure. So I made a strategy doc to get sign off where we made sure the exec team was aligned.

elements.text: we had a hunch it was partner managers but we werent sure. So I made a strategy doc to get sign off where we made sure the exec team was aligned.

text: I tried my best to say “this could change!” and went ahead by talking to dozens of people with that job description, asking them what kept them at night, what they read, and what they would like to see. That informed early content and created a bit of a feedback flywheel.

elements.text: I tried my best to say “this could change!” and went ahead by talking to dozens of people with that job description, asking them what kept them at night, what they read, and what they would like to see. That informed early content and created a bit of a feedback flywheel.

text: for example I heard “No one knows what I do” over and over and I suspected it was because there was no standard job title. So the wonderful <@UJ7R3QGSV> wrote <https://blog.crossbeam.com/partnership-job-titles|this>. Or people said “I dont know what good looks like, im making this up” we made sure to <https://blog.crossbeam.com/5-lessons-on-hyper-growth-partnerships-we-can-learn-from-slack|talk to heavy hitters like slack>.

text: <@ULJBEFSJJ> Luckily our founder is data obsessed so we built in attribution from the jump. I know that ~40% of the people who complete our onboarding have read at least one piece of content. We keep a close eye on that number and what spikes or drops it.

elements.text: Luckily our founder is data obsessed so we built in attribution from the jump. I know that ~40% of the people who complete our onboarding have read at least one piece of content. We keep a close eye on that number and what spikes or drops it.

text: We have similar numbers for those that convert from free to paid etc.

elements.text: We have similar numbers for those that convert from free to paid etc.

text: There is also the QUALITATIVE benefit. Example: Sales tells me that people always say “I love your content!” and I keep every mention of that. Example:

elements.text: There is also the QUALITATIVE benefit. Example: Sales tells me that people always say “I love your content!” and I keep every mention of that. Example:

text: Gold, Jerry, this is gold! :first_place_medal:

elements.text: Gold, Jerry, this is gold!

text: (which is also a good sign you’ve chosen the right audience!)

elements.text: (which is also a good sign you’ve chosen the right audience!)

text: <@U017WRJTKF1> Gated content, gated content, and more gated content. A big thing we heard over and over is “There is no roadmap, no guide, I dont know where to get best practices” so we put our heads down for 2 months and made <https://www.crossbeam.com/the-partner-playbook/|what is essentially a text book for partner people>. That’s been our biggest driver of new emails.

attachments.title: The Partner Playbook | Crossbeam
attachments.text: Drive revenue, get rewarded, and be an indispensable part of your company with insights from Zapier, Okta, Hubspot, RollWorks, and more.

elements.text: Gated content, gated content, and more gated content. A big thing we heard over and over is “There is no roadmap, no guide, I dont know where to get best practices” so we put our heads down for 2 months and made
what is essentially a text book for partner people
. That’s been our biggest driver of new emails.

text: we are only now picking up on webinars and (soon) live events

elements.text: we are only now picking up on webinars and (soon) live events

text: <@U01T8TVMUSD> Im a big believer that content IS branding and vice versa. So nothing is created for the top of funnel without him looking at it and (sometimes) designing it. We picked super unique colors, we have a unique illustration style where the image is tilted EXACTLY 17 degrees etc.

elements.text: Im a big believer that content IS branding and vice versa. So nothing is created for the top of funnel without him looking at it and (sometimes) designing it. We picked super unique colors, we have a unique illustration style where the image is tilted EXACTLY 17 degrees etc.

text: he does PDFs illustrations for each post, charts, presentations, social media graphics…. he’s awesome!

elements.text: he does PDFs illustrations for each post, charts, presentations, social media graphics…. he’s awesome!

text: that “slows us down” sometimes to have everything so custom but I believe it pays off in the long run and that less (but thoughtful) content is always better than more (but hurried)

elements.text: that “slows us down” sometimes to have everything so custom but I believe it pays off in the long run and that less (but thoughtful) content is always better than more (but hurried)

text: How do you create content ideas that seem to be SO specific to what is important to your audience? The appeal of the topics you write about seem to truly address the pain points of your audience

elements.text: How do you create content ideas that seem to be SO specific to what is important to your audience? The appeal of the topics you write about seem to truly address the pain points of your audience

text: <@U020GLH1U10> Nearly every post we write comes from a conversation with our audience. I’m talking an actual phone/zoom call. They will often express wanting to know something or struggling with something and thats our cue to find an answer. Or, conversely, we’ll ask “what part of your process are you proud of?” and we write posts from that. <https://blog.crossbeam.com/wp-engine-used-7-stage-bow-tie-funnel-to-increase-agency-partners-by-50|This is one our most popular posts> and it came from that convo. It’s so (perhaps overly) detailed, and that’s the point!

attachments.title: WP Engine Used This 7-Stage “Bow-Tie” Funnel to Increase Agency Partners by 50%
attachments.text: WP Engine’s Matt Irving on how he uses the bow-tie funnel to identify leading indicators of partner success, create a shared language with his leadership team, and measure the partnership org’s performance.
attachments.fallback: WP Engine Used This 7-Stage “Bow-Tie” Funnel to Increase Agency Partners by 50%

elements.text: Nearly every post we write comes from a conversation with our audience. I’m talking an actual phone/zoom call. They will often express wanting to know something or struggling with something and thats our cue to find an answer. This is one our most popular posts
and it came from that convo. It’s so (perhaps overly) detailed, and that’s the point!
